awd_titl_txt: PECASE: Modeling and Control of Neuronal Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
Objective: The proposed CAREER program involves modeling and control of neuronal networks in the brain and its application to the treatment of Parkinson?s disease (PD) using deep brain stimulation (DBS). Specific objectives are to: (i) construct a general approach for modeling complex neuronal networks where interactions occur between different brain nuclei, (ii) design computationally efficient control strategies for such networks, and (iii) apply these methodologies to the problem of restoring pathological network dynamics arising from PD with DBS. Success of the program will fundamentally impact the interface between control systems and neuroscience and create new opportunities for medical treatment of neurological disorders. 

Intellectual Merit: The work introduces a systems theoretic framework to (i) understand electrophysiology and pathophysiology of neuronal networks and the impact of DBS control, and (ii) design and explore new DBS strategies to treat PD with extensive simulation before experimenting on animals and translating to patients. The modeling framework will eventually lead to safer and potentially more therapeutic DBS for PD. The ultimate vision is to apply this transformative methodology to other neurological disorders (Dystonia, Depression, Obsessive Compulsive Disorders), impacting millions of patients worldwide. 

Broader Impact: The proposed plan will also impact education at all levels. It includes developing a new course for senior undergraduate and graduate students on modeling and DBS control of neural systems, and reaching out to women of all ages with unique workshops and internship opportunities. Finally, engineering students will be given the opportunity to perform electrophysiological experiments with collaborator at the Cleveland Clinic.

por.por_cntn:
This PECASE program involved modeling and control of neuronal networks in the brain and its application to the treatment of Parkinson’s disease (PD) using deep brain stimulation (DBS). Specific objectives were to: (i) construct a general approach for modeling complex neuronal networks where interactions occur between different brain nuclei, (ii) design computationally efficient control strategies for such networks, and (iii) apply these methodologies to the problem of restoring pathological network dynamics arising from PD with DBS.

Intellectual Merit: The work introduced a systems theoretic framework to (i) understand electrophysiology and pathophysiology of neuronal networks and the impact of DBS control, and (ii) design and explore new DBS strategies to treat PD with extensive simulation before experimenting on animals and translating to patients. The modeling framework will eventually lead to safer and potentially more therapeutic DBS for PD. The ultimate vision is to apply this transformative methodology to other neurological disorders (Epilepsy, Dystonia, Depression, Obsessive Compulsive Disorders), impacting millions of patients worldwide. In fact, during this award period, the program included supporting applications to epilepsy. Specifically, the computational framework developed here for PD was applied to solving important problems such as understanding where seizures start by observing neural activity before seizures start and then detecting when seizures start for early treatment.

Broader Impact: Just as my research builds upon the discoveries of other biomedical engineers and scientists, my educational activities with young people are, I hope, feeding the pipeline of future scientists to ensure continuing advancements in our field.  I made a particular effort to encourage girls and young women, for in my more than 30 engineering courses over 10 years of training at two universities I encountered only two female professors. Over the course of the PECASE award period, I gave talks at elementary schools and girl scout troop meetings, appeared as an engineer/neuroscientist expert on National Geographic's hit TV show "Brain Games" (watched by several young girls and boys), visited female high school students at Baltimore Polytechnical Institute to inspire students to pursue a higher education in STEM fields, and gave talks at special events and conferences aimed to promote STEM careers. I also developed a new senior-level undergraduate/graduate course on "Networks" at JHU which covered graph theory and applications in neuroscience, which received excellent reviews.

Award Outcomes: This PECASE had a fundamental impact on the interface between control systems and neuroscience and created new opportunities for medical treatment of neurological disorders. It has resulted in 15 publications in premier Science, Neuroscience and Engineering Journals, including PNAS, Journal of Neuroscience, and IEEE Transactions on Neural Systems and Rehabilitation Engineering and several peer-review conference proceedings.
